I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  India  for  the  Agribusiness  Infrastructure  Development 
Investment Program. 1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
2. 
The  investment  program  aims to  address  three main constraints  on  agriculture growth: 
(i) outdated technologies and management; (ii) lack of public investment in linking infrastructure 
(such  as  roads  from  production  areas  to  collection  points);  and  (iii)  lack  of  private  investment 
and  management  in  modern  marketing  infrastructure  (such  as  cold  chains,  controlled 
atmosphere storages, and automated grading). Using an integrated value chain (IVC) approach, 
the  investment  program  will  invest  in  physical  and  institutional  links  along  horticultural  value 
chains 2  by  supporting  (i)  site  development  and  agribusiness  infrastructure,  (ii)  linking 
infrastructure  to  ensure  connectivity  and  basic  services  across  the  value  chain,  (iii)  backward 
links  to  the  production  areas  through  contract  farming  and  producer  companies,  and  
(iv)  capacity  building  to  strengthen  technical  and  managerial  skills  along  the  value  chain.  The 
investment  program  area  covers  selected  regions  of  Bihar  and  Maharashtra,  two  states  that 
have  adopted  different  agri-marketing  policies:  Bihar  promotes  the  provision  of  agri-marketing 
as  a  private-sector-led  function,  and  Maharashtra  enables  greater  private  sector  participation 
but leaves the role of regulator and market manager with the public sector. 
 

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
In  2009,  agriculture  contributed  16%  of  the  national  gross  domestic  product.  However, 
58%  of  the  workforce  continues  to  rely  on  agriculture  for  both  income  and  livelihood. 3 The 
Eleventh Five-Year Plan (2007–2012) targets an agriculture sector growth rate of 4%, bringing 
higher  farmer  incomes  and  more  employment  opportunities  in  rural  areas,  and  therefore 
promoting  inclusive  economic  growth. 4  However,  agriculture  failed  to  achieve  the  planned 
growth  rates  for  the  previous  two  plan  periods,  leaving  rural  areas  in  pervasive  poverty.  The 
deceleration in agricultural growth, as a result of not catalyzing private investment, has further 
accentuated  the  rural–urban  divide.  Higher  incomes  and  employment  opportunities  in  rural 
areas  are  necessary  to  benefit  rural  households,  boost  off-farm  incomes,  redress  the  rural–
urban imbalance, and promote inclusive economic growth. Against this backdrop, the Eleventh 
Five-Year  Plan  targets  (i)  a  modern  efficient  marketing  infrastructure,  (ii)  backward  links 
between  markets  and  production  areas  to  give  producers  higher  prices,  and  (iii)  coordination 
along the agricultural value chains. Private sector participation in all these activities is necessary 
to bring world-class technology and modern management to agri-marketing, and policy reforms 
have  been  undertaken  to  allow  this.  To  attract  private  investment,  the  Government  of  India’s 
policy  framework  for  the  sector  promotes  public–private  partnerships  (PPPs),  and  provides 
public  sector  capital  grants  to  private  sector  investors  wanting  to  establish  agribusiness 
infrastructure with backward links. However, these are still in their infancy.

 Public–private  partnership.  The  Government  of  India  estimates  that  infrastructure 
4. 
investment of 8% of gross domestic product ($457 billion) is required to achieve the growth rate 
targets  of  the  Eleventh  Five-Year  Plan,  with  the  private  sector  providing  30%  through  PPPs. 
PPPs  have  gained  prominence  in  the  last  5  years,  especially  for  roads,  telecommunications, 
and power, where 450 PPP contracts so far total $50 billion. Although agriculture is not a focus 
sector,  the  plan  envisages  private  sector  investment  in  and  management  of  marketing 
infrastructure, including modern logistics, cold chains, markets, and food processing plants.   
 
The  role  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  within  the  government  strategy,  as 
5. 
identified  in  the  country  partnership  strategy  for  2009–2012,5 targets  higher  producer  returns 
and  more  private  investment  through  PPPs.  The  investment  program  seeks  (i)  to  develop 
spatially  and  institutionally  linked  IVCs  for  horticultural  high-value  crops  (HVCs),  and  (ii)  to 
enable small producers to associate in groups that can further evolve into producer companies 
to bargain for marketing opportunities. The supply of modern infrastructure under private sector 
management  will  improve product quality, reduce post-harvest  waste,  and  add value  to lower-
value  produce.  As  such,  the  investment  program  is  consistent  with  the  country  partnership 
strategy  and  with  the  ADB  Operational  Plan  for  Sustainable  Food  Security,6 which  suggests 
increasing synergy and value addition in backward and forward links along the agricultural value 
chains. Further, the investment program will pioneer the mainstreaming of PPPs in agriculture, 
targeting stronger capital formation in the sector. 
 
6. 
Value  chain  approach.  The  process  and  underlying  structure  of  the  investment 
program adopts an IVC approach.  By influencing the structures, systems, and relationships that 
define the value chain, the aim is to help farmers, traders, and other value chain stakeholders to 
improve  their  products  and  processes,  increasing the  contribution  of  value  chain  output  to  the 
benefit  of  all  the  members.  The  focus  of  the  IVC  approach  is  on  transforming  relationships, 
particularly  between  players  linked  vertically  in  the  value  chain,  to  help  them  upgrade  and 
become competitive, and to adapt to changes in end markets to remain competitive.  
 
7. 
The  investment  program  will  actively  pursue  cooperation  and  synergies  with  other 
development  partners,  including  (i)  the  World  Bank  National  Agricultural  Innovation  Project, 
2006–2012;  (ii)  the  planned  World  Bank  Multi-State  Agriculture  Competitiveness  Program, 
2010–2016;  and  (iii)  the  International  Fund  for  Agricultural  Development  Convergence  of 
Agricultural Interventions in Maharashtra, 2009–2017. While ADB has undertaken agribusiness 
programs  in  the  South  Asia  region,  its  general  support  for  PPPs  is  limited  (there  have  been 
none  in  the  sector).  The  following  key  lessons  were  incorporated  in  the  investment  program 
design:  (i)  agriculture  projects  promoting  diversification  into  HVCs  are  key  for  promoting 
inclusive  economic  growth  and  creating  opportunities  for  employment 
in  rural  areas,  
(ii) changing the incentives for value chain stakeholders to respond to market demand signals is 
the  most  effective  use  of  funds,  (iii)  farmer  organizations  involving  small  farmers  need  to  be 
strengthened to increase their bargaining capability within the value chain, (iv) more cooperation 
between  public  and  private  sectors  is  necessary  to  ensure  agriculture  commercialization,  and 
(v) the structure of PPPs needs to be customized for development. 
 
The  government  of  Bihar  seeks  to  move  the  provision  and  the  management  of 
8. 
agribusiness  facilities  to  the  private  sector.  A  key  policy  for  Bihar  is  the  building  of  marketing 
networks that operate as linked hierarchies from modern terminal markets, through agribusiness 
centers,  to  rural  centers  including  on-farm,  first-step  processing  facilities.  Total  estimated

the 2010–2015 period. The state government plans to invest up to 20% of this requirement. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

9. 
The  impact  of  the  investment  program  will  be  higher  value  of  horticulture  products 
captured by the stakeholders of the IVCs in selected regions of Bihar and Maharashtra, as the 
private  sector  brings  in  world-class  technology  and  modern  management.  The  investment 
program  outcome  will  be  the  investment  in  and  management  of  eight  or  more IVCs,  including 
small-scale farmers, by the private sector.  
 
The  outcome  of  the  investment  program  will  be  delivered  through  eight  or  more  PPP 
10. 
contracts to private sector concessionaires, selected in a transparent and competitive way, who 
will design, build, finance, operate, and maintain the IVCs. To attract private sector investors, a 
public sector capital grant will be provided to a concessionaire, the bidding parameter being the 
total  amount  of  capital  grant  required  for  the  bidder  to  accept  the  contract.  Attracting 
investments from the private sector in agricultural marketing poses different challenges in Bihar 
and  Maharashtra,  making  it  necessary  to  use  different  PPP  approaches  to  the  perceived 
business risks in each state. The maximum capital grant available to bidders will be 70% of the 
total  investment  cost  in  Bihar  and  40%  in  Maharashtra.  Bihar’s  model  requires  that  the 
concessionaire  will  pay  30%  of  the  IVC  gross  revenue  stream  back  to  the  government. 
Concessionaires in Maharashtra will provide more investment up front than in Bihar, but will not 
share  future  revenues  with  the  state.  These  PPP  models  may  be  revised  based  on  the 
government’s  experience  in  implementing  the  AIDIP  and  other  sector  PPP  programs,  market 
conditions,  and  related  supporting  government  policies.  Selected  concessionaires  will  finalize 
design,  procure  works,  and  fully  manage  the  IVC  infrastructure. In  this  way,  the  investment

Outputs 

11. 
The investment program outputs include (i) functional IVC infrastructure, (ii) stakeholders 
effectively  participating  in  and  properly  managing  the  IVCs,  and  (iii)  state  governments 
efficiently  performing  their  regulatory  and  oversight  functions  over  the  IVCs  and  the  PPP 
contracts.  The  investment  program  outputs  will  be  delivered  through  two  components:  
(i) support for IVCs, and (ii) institutional development and program management.   
 

1.  

Support for Integrated Value Chains 

 
12. 
This component will support the strengthening and/or establishment of infrastructure and 
institutional links among the value chain stakeholders for horticultural HVCs. The component will 
ensure  that  IVCs  are  operational  by  financing  basic  and  agribusiness  infrastructure,  linking 
infrastructure  to  ensure  connectivity  and  basic  utilities,  strengthening  and/or  establishing 
backward  links,  and  supporting  technical  and  managerial  skills  development  along  the  value 

3

and  links  among  value  chain  stakeholders,  including  farmers,  processors,  agribusiness 
entrepreneurs, and service providers, which, along with the infrastructure support, will make the 
IVCs functional.

Rehabilitation  and  construction  of  agribusiness  infrastructure,  operated  by  the

storage.7 
Establishment of linking infrastructure along the value chain, i.e., infrastructure to 
provide the IVC with basic utilities (such as power and water) and to increase the 
IVC connectivity through proper  roads (such as rural roads to production areas, 
and access roads to markets).8 
Strengthening and/or establishing IVC backward links to the production areas so 
that  producers  can  participate  in  the  IVC  activities.  To  take  advantage  of  better 
marketing efficiency and value-adding options along the IVC, small farmers must 
coordinate  their  decisions,  aggregate  their  produce,  and  improve  their  product 
quality.  To  develop  farmers'  capacity  to  do  so,  the  investment  program  will 
organize  small  producers  into  farmer  companies  and  will  provide  farmers  with 
training  in  value  addition  to  improve  their  production  and  marketing  decisions, 
increase their marketing efficiency, and raise their profitability.9  
Capacity  development  along  the  IVC  to  enhance  the  capability  in technical  and 
managerial skills to operate IVCs will be provided by the concessionaire and the 
executing  agency,  according  to  the  needs.  The  capacity  development  activities 
for  the  technical  skills  will  be  determined  by  the  equipment  bought  and  the 
facilities established along the IVC and will be purchased by the concessionaire 
jointly  with  specific  IVC  equipment.  The  capacity  development  activities  for  the 
managerial skills will be provided by the executing agency as needed.  

2. 

Institutional Development and Program Management 

 
13. 
To  establish  sound  project  and  PPP  contract  management  systems,  program 
management units (PMUs) in each state will provide implementation support, consisting of staff, 
office facilities and equipment, consulting services, and liaison and coordination with other  line 
agencies.  There  will  be  baseline  surveys,  and  regular  monitoring  and  evaluation.  PMUs  will 
establish  and  maintain  a  website  with  information  on  project  activities,  including  procurement 
procedures  and  results.  A  technical  advisory  group  (TAG)  with  the  requisite  experience  and 
skills will be engaged by each PMU to ensure that the PPP transactions for the establishment of 
the IVC infrastructure are successfully completed and their implementation monitored. The role

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

17. 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 
the Facility Administration Manual (FAM) (Appendix 2). The executing agencies for the MFF will 
be  the  Bihar  Department  of  Agriculture  and  the  Maharashtra  Department  of  Cooperation, 
Marketing  and  Textile.  The  implementing  agencies  will  be  PMUs  within  the  Department  of 
Agriculture  in  Bihar  and  the  Maharashtra  State  Agriculture  Marketing  Board  in  Maharashtra. 
They  will  coordinate  overall  implementation  of  the  projects  through  administrative  support, 
contracting  of  the  PPP  transactions,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  and  financial  management. 
Each PMU will subcontract professional experts to support the bidding process, the preparation 
of  detailed  project  reports  for  subsequent  PFRs,  and  the  implementation  of  capacity 
development  activities.  All  IVC  projects  to  be  included  under  the  MFF  will  meet  the  selection 
criteria  in Schedule  4 of  the  FFA.  The  PMUs  will  invite  bids  from the  private  sector to design, 
construct, operate, and maintain the IVC infrastructure, as described in para. 12, (i) and (ii), and 
will contract them on a PPP basis, with land provided by the government.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Economic and Financial 

18. 
The  IVCs  to  be  financed  by  the  MFF  under  PFR1  (Muzaffarpur  and  Nalanda–Patna 
regions  of  Bihar)  are  assessed  to  be  economically  feasible,  with  economic  internal  rates  of 
return  (EIRR)  ranging  from  19.0%  to  24.0%.  When  all  IVCs  are  combined  and  their 
management  and  institutional  costs  are  included,  the  EIRR  remains  at  15.9%,  indicating 
sufficiently high economic return compared with the discount rate of 12.0%. Sensitivity analysis 

7 

 

 of the EIRR for PFR1 for additional overheads for the PMU and different sharing of institutional 
costs between PFR1 and the subsequent PFRs shows that the EIRR increases to 16.3%. 
 
19. 
The  financial  sustainability  of  the  investment  and  the  implementing  agency's  ability  to 
support  the  financial  costs  for  managing  the  two  concession  agreements  was  assessed.  The 
financial assessment of the PPP models indicate that the revenue-sharing agreement with the 
concessionaires  will  cover  the  expected  costs  per  annum  for  maintaining  PMU  staffing  and 
operation, showing no risk to financial sustainability. A major impact of the investment program 
will  be  to  provide  proof  of  concept  for  the  use  of  PPPs  for  agri-marketing  facilities  and  their 
management.  The  investment  program  will  catalyze  investment  from  the  private  sector  in 
agribusiness  infrastructure,  bringing  modern  technology  and  providing  better  services  to  the 
value chain users. This will have significant post-investment program multiplier effects through 
adoption  of  more  advanced  technologies  brought  in  by  the  private  sector,  and  broader 
processing  and  marketing  opportunities.  The  higher  returns  to  the  stakeholders  of  the  value 
chains will ensure that the IVC will be sustainable (Appendix 2) 
 
B. 

Governance 

20. 
The  executing  agencies  have  limited  experience  in  implementing  externally  funded 
projects,  but  have  the  organizational  structure,  skills,  and  financial  management  system 
required  to  implement  them.  A  financial  management  assessment  was  carried  out  and 
confirmed  that  the  proposed  executing  agencies  follow  the  Government  of  India's  General 
Finance  Rules  (2005)  and  use  accounting  systems  compatible  with  international  accounting 
standards.  There  are  no  major  issues  with  the  accounting  policies  and  procedures.  However, 
some measures to boost governance of the investment program will include (i) preparation of a 
financial  management  manual  for  the  investment  program;  (ii)  the  requirement  for  PMUs  to 
follow government rules and procedures for all expense and capital items, including cash, and 
the  proper  maintenance  of  financial  records;  and  (iii)  the  requirement  for  PMUs  to  hire  the 
proper  financial  staff  as  agreed  with  ADB.  An  independent  auditor  acceptable  to  ADB  will 
annually  audit  all  investment  program-related  accounts,  statements  of  expenditure,  and 
revenues.  All  audit  reports  and  certified financial statements  will  be  submitted  to  ADB  within  6 
months of the close of the year under audit. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to 
date)  was  explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  government  and  executing  agencies.  The 
specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the FAM. 
 
C. 

Poverty and Social 

21. 
The investment program will promote inclusive economic growth and food security, and 
will  directly  benefit  the  rural  areas,  by  creating  employment opportunities  on-farm  and  off-farm 
activities and increasing farm gate prices. Although the primary focus of the investment program 
is on making the horticultural value chains modern and efficient, a significant number of poor are 
also likely to be beneficiaries of the  projects, because over 60% of small and medium farmers 
and  small  traders  belong  to  socially  backward  communities. Vulnerable groups  were  identified 
and  estimated  in  all  the  project  districts.  Under  tranche  1,  it  is  estimated  that  300  full-time 
employees  will  work  for  the  IVCs,  a  further  3,486  day  workers  will  be  provided  with  additional 
300  days  of  work  per  year,  and  a  total  of  112,300  suppliers  will  directly  benefit  from  the 
investment,  through  higher  returns  from  crop  production,  reduced  post-harvest  losses  (20%–
30%),  and  increased  value  addition  along  the  IVCs.  The  landless  poor  will  benefit  from  the 
creation  of  additional  employment  opportunities  along  the  IVCs  and  ancillary  industries. 
Boosting  the  capacity  of  farmer  groups  will  raise  their  bargaining  power  and  link  them  more 
effectively to the value chain.  

8 
 

 

  
22. 
In  rural  areas,  the  workforce  participation  rate  for  women  is  27.2%  (nearly  thrice  as 
much  as  the  urban  female  participation  rate  of  9.7%),  and  89.5%  of  all  women  employed  are 
engaged in the agriculture and allied industrial sector. Women in both states play a key role in 
all  aspects  of  agriculture  from  sowing  to  selling  of  the  produce.  However,  women  are  not 
substantively involved in decisions about the production and marketing of produce, and tend to 
market their produce through middlemen.  Furthermore, 60%–80% of women cultivators in the 
investment  program  areas  belong 
to  marginalized  and  other  backward  communities. 
Empowering  female  agricultural  workers  through  participation  in  farmer  societies  will  give 
women  a  voice  in  decision  making  and  will  integrate  them  in  the  value  chain.  Their  effective 
integration into the value chain will raise their incomes and reduce wage discrimination, thereby 
supporting  accomplishment  of  core  labor  standards  in  a  sector  where  a  large  part  of  the 
production is in the informal sector. 
 
23. 
The rural focus of the investment program helps address the growing rural–urban divide 
in  the  incidence  of  poverty  and  economic  development  of  the  country.  Also,  complementing 
public  sector  investment  with  private  investment  will  accelerate  growth,  employment,  and 
economic  prosperity  in  rural  areas.  Provision  of  linking  infrastructure  will  help  complete  the 
connectivity, reduce costs, increase mobility, and have supplementary social benefits.11 
 
D. 

Safeguards 

24. 
An  Environmental  Assessment  and  Review  Framework  was  developed  for  the  MFF 
(Appendix  2).  Proposed  investments  under  tranche  1  in  Bihar  are  classified  as  environmental 
category B, and an initial environmental examination (IEE) with an environmental management 
plan  (EMP)  was prepared in accordance with ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The 
IEE  concludes  that  there  will  be  no  significant  adverse  impact,  and  most  of  the  impacts 
predicted are temporary, typical and easy to alleviate with the mitigating measures suggested in 
the EMP, such as dust generation and noise during construction. Better infrastructure will allow 
better  systems  to  manage  solid  and  liquid  waste,  and  stronger  traffic  management  within  the 
facilities, resulting in  environmental  improvements.  In the  preparation  of the IEE,  consultations 
were  held  with  farmers,  potentially  affected  traders,  government,  and  potential  private 
developers.  During  detailed  engineering  stages,  the  potential  developers  will  conduct  further 
consultations,  update the  EMP  and  IEE  as  needed,  and  make  all  environmental  assessments 
available  to  the  general  public  in  a  form  that  concerned  people  and  other  stakeholders  can 
understand. While the implementation of the EMP will be the responsibility of the IVC developer, 
each  state  pollution  control  board  and  PMU  will  be  responsible  for  ensuring  effective 
implementation  of  the  EMP.  The  PMUs  will  be  provided  with  environmental  consultants,  if  so 
required, to supplement government staff for environmental monitoring. 
 
The  envisioned  interventions  will  not  have  adverse  social  or  resettlement  impacts,  or 
25. 
negative effects on indigenous peoples and ethnic minority groups. Construction will take place 
on government land and existing rights of way. The investment program will exclude any parts 
that  would  entail  land  acquisition  or  involuntary  resettlement  (IR),  including  relocation.12 The 
locations of the first two tranches do not involve areas with indigenous peoples (IP) and ethnic 
minority groups.13 For this, the proposed investments under tranche 1 in Bihar are classified as  
category C for IR and IP.

IV. 

ASSURANCES 

27. 
The Government of India, the Government of Bihar, and the Government of Maharashtra 
have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  investment  program  shall  conform  to  all 
applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  procurement, 
consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as  described  in  detail  in the  FAM  and  loan documents. 
The Government of India, the Government of Bihar, and the Government of Maharashtra have 
given ADB certain undertakings for the MFF, which are set forth in the FFA. Specific covenants 
with  respect  to  individual  tranches  under  the  MFF  will  be  set  forth  in  the  loan  agreement  and 
project agreement for the respective tranches.
